title: Driving Speed and Stopping Distance
question_text:
Examine the scatterplot below, used to predict stopping distance based off motoristsâ€™ speed.

Which feature does this scatterplot show that might make one hesitate to use this as a model for prediction?

choices.text: The correlation is weak to moderate.
More pieces of data should be used to make predictions more reliable.
As speed increases, there seems to be more variability in stopping distance.
The stopping distance seems to level off as speed increases.
There is no data in the speed range past $40\text{ miles per hour}$.

solution:
The data appears to be much more spread out at higher speeds, making predictions less accurate.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; the correlation appears strong.

Choice 'B' is incorrect; there is more than enough data for this scatterplot.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; the data does NOT level off; if anything, there is a slight increase in the scatterplot at higher speeds.

Choice 'E' is incorrect; this might be a problem if one wanted to use this model for speeds of faster than $40$ miles per hour, but otherwise, it is suitable for speeds up to $40$ miles per hour.
